content: Aurora Kinase A (AURKA) is an oncogenic kinase with major roles in mitosis, but also exerts cell cycle- and kinase-independent functions linked to cancer. Therefore control of its expression, as well as its activity, is crucial. A short and a long 3â€™UTR isoform exist for AURKA mRNA, resulting from alternative polyadenylation (APA). We initially observed that in Triple Negative Breast Cancer, where AURKA is typically overexpressed, the short isoform is predominant and this correlates with faster relapse times of patients. The short isoform is characterized by higher translational efficiency since translation and decay rate of the long isoform are targeted by

regulates the cell cycle periodicity of translation of the long isoform, whereas the short isoform is translated highly and constantly throughout interphase. Finally, disrupted production of the long isoform led to an increase in proliferation and migration rates of cells. In sum, we uncovered a new mechanism dependent on the cooperation between APA and miRNA targeting likely to be a route of oncogenic activation of human AURKA.

title: Differential translation of mRNA isoforms underlies oncogenic activation of cell cycle kinase Aurora A

authorNotes.text: To whom correspondence should be addressed. Email: Roberta Cacioppo rc781@cam.ac.uk or Catherine Lindon acl34@cam.ac.uk.

content: Aurora Kinase A (AURKA) is a critical positive regulator of the mitotic phase of the cell cycle (
). AURKA also plays additional cancer-promoting roles in cell proliferation, survival, migration, and cancer stem cell phenotypes, some of which in interphase and in a kinase-independent manner (
). AURKA expression follows a strict cell cycle-dependent pattern, with both protein and mRNA levels extremely low in G
phase, increasing in S phase, and peaking at G
). High expression of AURKA is strongly associated with cancer progression, drug resistance and poor prognosis, justifying why oncogenic AURKA represents a renowned target of anti-cancer drugs (
), and making evident that oncogenic roles of AURKA are prompted by its highly sustained levels of expression.

AURKA overexpression in human cancers is known to be caused by elevated gene copy number, enhanced transcription or increased protein stability. Dysregulation of translation is also linked to disease and contributions of dysregulated translation to cancer phenotypes are increasingly reported (
). Despite some modest evidence suggests that modulation of AURKA translation is relevant in disease (
), control of AURKA expression at the level of translation is widely understudied compared with control of its transcription and mRNA processing (

). For example, it is not clear whether AURKA mRNA undergoes translational activation and/or inhibition during the cell cycle, and the precise timing, extent or regulators of these processes remain unexplored.

The process of cleavage of the 3â€™end of precursor mRNAs (pre-mRNAs) and concomitant addition of a poly(A) tail represents one key event aiding the maturation of mRNAs, termed cleavage and polyadenylation (C/P) (

). The cleavage site is typically preceded by a polyadenylation signal (PAS), located 10â€“30 nucleotides (nt) upstream, and by UGUA and U-rich motifs, whereas it is typically followed by U- and GU-rich motifs. Altogether, these elements constitute the C/P site (
). Most human pre-mRNAs contain multiple C/P sites (
), enabling alternative cleavage and polyadenylation (APA) and, thus, distinct expression of transcript isoforms for the same gene. A search using PolyA_DB (
) indicates presence of two C/P sites with canonical PASs (AATAAA) on AURKA 3â€™ untranslated region (3â€™UTR) (

). This fostered our hypothesis that AURKA mRNA could be subjected to tandem 3â€™UTR APA, resulting in two 3â€™UTR isoforms that differ in length. It is currently unknown which AURKA PAS is preferentially used in which cellular context or whether a 3â€™UTR isoform switch can be modulatable.
Increased short/long ratio (SLR) of AURKA APA isoforms in TNBC
AURKA transcript isoforms (USCS Genome Browser). AURKA gene is located on (-) strand.
Median and range of SLR values for AURKA 3â€™UTR obtained using APADetect. Mann-Whitney test; ****, p<0.0001.
RT-qPCR analysis of SLR of AURKA 3â€™UTR in TNBC cell lines (C) and patient samples (D). SDHA used as reference gene. TN, tissue number.
Relapse-free survival rates of TNBC patients with high (highest 25%) or low (lowest 25%) AURKA SLRs. p value determined by log-rank test.
APA is involved in most cellular processes and is often altered in cancer (
). Clinically, human cancers are characterized by unique profiles of alternative 3â€™UTRs that can be exploited for classification of distinct cancer subtypes (
), and associations between 3â€™UTR shortening and poor prognosis (
) have been detected. At the molecular level, a strong positive association between expression of short 3â€™UTRs, increased protein levels and proliferative states has been frequently reported (
). Such genome-wide 3â€™UTR shortening sustains cancer cell behavior by removing repressor sequence elements from the 3â€™UTR of oncogenic mRNAs, for example microRNA (miRNA) binding sites (
), or alternatively by inactivating tumor suppressors through suppression of their expression (
The role of miRNAs in regulating cell cycle genes and the relevance of this regulation in cancer are well understood (

). Few miRNAs have been pointed to as regulators of AURKA mRNA but, importantly, reported cases of miRNA targeting of AURKA occur in those cancers where AURKA overexpression is a promoting factor or a marker of poor prognosis (
). Regardless, none of these studies consider the existence of distinct AURKA 3â€™UTR isoforms in their experimental design of targeting assessment. The

miRNA family comprises 11 closely related genes that map in chromosomal regions that are typically deleted in human tumors and, given their pathogenic downregulation in cancer, they are classified as tumor suppressors (
in breast tumor growth and metastasis have been proposed (
expression and clinical variables has been detected in TNBC (
AURKA was classified within the Triple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC) subtype with the highest median index of 3â€™UTR shortening events (
), and also undergoes 3â€™UTR shortening in poor-prognosis patients of breast and lung cancer (
). Importantly, AURKA overexpression in TNBC represents a marker of early recurrence, poor prognosis, and shorter overall survival (

). However, the correlation between AURKA PAS usage, protein expression and pathological cell behavior has not been explored for this or other biological contexts, nor at the molecular level. In this study, we uncover a molecular mechanism leveraging the cellular ratio of APA isoforms and their different translational program during the cell cycle to control acquisition of AURKA oncogenic potential.
Increased short/long ratio of AURKA APA isoforms in TNBC
In a preliminary study using the APADetect
tool, we analysed publicly available microarray data to identify changes in AURKA 3â€™UTR isoform abundance in tissues (
). 520 comparable datasets for TNBC samples came from GSE31519 (
) and 65 histologically normal epithelium and cancer-free prophylactic mastectomy patients were used: 32 from GSE20437 (
). The analysis revealed increased short/long ratio (SLR) of AURKA 3â€™UTR isoforms in TNBC compared to normal breast tissues (
). Higher SLR was confirmed by RT-qPCR in multiple TNBC cell lines (
). Furthermore, RT-qPCR analysis of normal and TNBC patient cDNAs from Origene Breast Cancer cDNA array IV (BCRT504) also showed higher AURKA SLR in TNBC samples compared to normal (
). In addition, the shortening of AURKA 3â€™UTR correlated with faster relapse times in TNBC patients (clinical data from (
). These results therefore suggest a potential oncogenic role of AURKA APA in breast cancer worth further investigations.

To probe AURKA APA isoform-dependent protein expression, we developed a single-cell expression sensor suitable for experiments in live cell. The construct independently expresses Venus and mCherry fluorescent proteins via a constitutive bi-directional promoter (

). The coding sequence (CDS) of Venus is flanked by AURKA UTRs, whereas that of mCherry lacks regulatory regions and is therefore used to normalize for transfection efficiency. To test for APA-sensitive expression, we alternatively mutated the distal (d) or proximal (p) PAS on the reporter 3â€™UTR, to generate different 3â€™UTR isoforms (SHORT and LONG, respectively). Constructs lacking AURKA UTRs (Î”) and expressing AURKA wild-type UTRs (WT) were used as controls.
. UTR-dependent protein expression reporters. Venus CDS is flanked by AURKA 5â€™UTR and 3â€™UTR, WT or PAS-mutated.
. Representative snapshots of transfected U2OS. Scale bar 50Î¼m.

Mean and s.e.m. of median Venus/mCherry MFI ratios from transfected U2OS from three biological replicates. n â‰¥ 129 cells per condition. Ordinary one-way ANOVA with Tukeyâ€™s multiple comparisons test.
RT-qPCR of endogenous AURKA SLR in U2OS. Long isoform abundance plotted as fold change over total AURKA mRNA. 18S rRNA used as reference target.
) cells. n â‰¥ 55 cells per condition. Unpaired t-test. ns, not significant; *, p<0.05; **, p<0.01; ***, p<0.001.
We initially assessed the efficiency of the promoter bidirectionality. Correlation between Venus and mCherry expression was strongly maintained at the level of both fluorescence intensity (
). Promoter strength was however not equal in both directions, since fewer copies of mCherry mRNA were transcribed compared to Venus mRNA (
), despite mCherry fluorescence intensity being generally higher than that of Venus (
, see Î”). We further assessed that mRNA of both mCherry and Venus was stable over time (
, see Î”), and fluorescence of both proteins was stable over time and over different cell cycle stages (
). Considering the short maturation time and long half-life of both Venus and mCherry proteins (

), the assay allows to reliably measure effects of UTRs on reporter protein levels at any given time and regardless of cell cycle phases. As positive control of our assay, we recapitulated the higher protein expression from the short 3â€™UTR APA isoform of CDC6 mRNA, which has previously been observed (
AURKA APA isoforms are translated with different efficiency

RT-qPCR of reporter mRNAs abundance (A) and decay rate (B) from transfected U2OS. mCherry mRNA used as reference target. Ordinary one-way ANOVA with Tukeyâ€™s multiple comparisons test; ns, not significant.
Decay rate of endogenous AURKA mRNA as in (B). 18S rRNA used as reference target. Abundance of long isoform plotted as fold change over total AURKA mRNA.
Design of the Nascent Chain Immunoprecipitation (NC IP) reporters and assay.
Mean and s.e.m. of median FlagVenus/mCherry MFI ratios from transfected U2OS from two biological replicates. n â‰¥ 160 cells per condition. Unpaired t-test; **, p<0.005.
Immunoblots of NC IP fractions using Î” (F) or Flag-Î” (G) reporter. mCherry used as negative control.
RT-qPCR of eluted reporter mRNAs. Results representative of three biological replicates.
Addition of AURKA UTRs to Venus CDS significantly increased protein expression (
), likely due to the role of 5â€™UTR in facilitating translation (
). We found that the SHORT reporter generates significantly more protein compared to the LONG (

). Moreover, similar protein expression levels from the WT and LONG reporters suggest that AURKA WT 3â€™UTR is processed with a preference for dPAS in U2OS cells. Accordingly, we could detect both endogenous AURKA APA isoforms in U2OS cells by 3â€™RACE (
) and confirmed by RT-qPCR that AURKA long isoform is prevalent (âˆ¼60% of total AURKA mRNA) (
). The different SLR observed between U2OS cells, normal breast tissues and TNBC cell lines and tissues (

) indicates that AURKA 3â€™UTR isoform prevalence is dependent on cell type. In addition, the quantitative difference in reporter protein expression by the isoforms also varied among cell types, suggesting cell-specific regulation (
, SHORT vs LONG). In sum, these results provide evidence for the first time of a role for APA in controlling AURKA protein expression.
AURKA APA isoforms are translated with different efficiency
We next investigated the basis of the different protein expression between AURKA APA isoforms. Following transfection of U2OS cells with the constructs in
, we first quantified the abundance of reporter mRNA isoforms (
). We then assessed the isoforms decay rate by quantifying reporter mRNAs at multiple time points following arrest of transcription by Actinomycin D (ActD) (
). We observed that while Venus mRNA lacking UTRs was highly stable, reporter mRNA levels decreased at faster rate when carrying UTRs (
), indicating that the assay reports on UTR-dependent effects on mRNA stability. Both the abundance and stability of the SHORT and LONG reporter isoforms were similar (
). We additionally found that the two endogenous AURKA 3â€™UTR isoforms also have similar decay rates, albeit decaying at a higher rate compared to the reporter mRNAs (
), suggesting that features present in AURKA CDS might influence mRNA stability (

Because the reporter APA isoforms share similar abundance and stability, we wondered whether they undergo different translational regulation instead. To this aim, we adapted a biochemical translation efficiency (TE) assay from Williams
), which required addition of a 3XFlag tag to the N-terminus of Venus (FlagVenus) in our reporter constructs, and called this Nascent Chain Immunoprecipitation (NC IP) assay (
). We first assessed that addition of the 3XFlag tag did not alter Venus expression (

). In our NC IP assay, anti-Flag beads were used to immunoprecipitate nascent FlagVenus chains from ribosomes stalled by treatment with cycloheximide (CHX). Ribosome-mRNA complexes were eluted from the IP-immobilized nascent chains using puromycin, which causes release of nascent chains from ribosomes (

); RNA was then purified from the elution fraction and quantified by RT-qPCR to provide a measure of the amount of reporter mRNA undergoing translation. All fractions were then blotted for FlagVenus and mCherry (negative control) proteins to monitor their presence at different steps of the experiment. As expected, elution with puromycin retained FlagVenus on the beads, whereas mCherry, as well as untagged Venus, are lost in the flow-through (

). No reporter mRNA could be detected in the elution fraction when untagged Venus was used (data not shown). Alternatively, purified 3XFlag peptide was used to elute the nascent chain-ribosome-mRNA complexes from the beads following IP (
). RT-qPCR quantification of the FlagVenus nascent chain-cognate reporter mRNAs revealed about twice more copies of Flag-S mRNA compared to Flag-L mRNA, regardless of the elution method (

). This indicates that Flag-S mRNA is translated with higher efficiency than Flag-L mRNA. These results show that APA controls AURKA protein expression mainly via differential translational regulation of the 3â€™UTR isoforms.
Translation rate of AURKA APA isoforms follows different cell cycle periodicity
Given the known cell cycle-dependent expression of AURKA (

), we tested whether differential translational efficiency of AURKA mRNA isoforms might contribute to this regulation. To avoid perturbation of translation provoked by classical cell synchronization methods (
), we used a live-cell fluorescence-based translation rate measurement assay in conjunction with a CDK2 activity sensor (
cell cycle synchronization. We developed our assay of â€˜Translation Rate Imaging by rate of Protein Stabilizationâ€™ (TRIPS) based on a previously introduced reporter system (
). Our bidirectional promoter construct was modified to express superfolder GFP (sfGFP) fused to a mutated

dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR-Y100I) destabilizer domain (DHFR-sfGFP), which is continuously degraded unless the stabilizer molecule trimethoprim (TMP) is added. Addition of TMP leads to an increase of sfGFP signal over time and, given the sfGFP short maturation time (
), the accumulation rate of sfGFP reflects DHFR-sfGFP protein synthesis rate (

). The ratio of the median of single-cell mCherry-normalized sfGFP signals at 2h to that at 0h of TMP treatment was therefore used as read-out for bulk translation rate. In accordance with our assay being designed to measure translation rate, sfGFP signal could not increase under TMP treatment in the presence of translation inhibitor CHX (
). We also ensured that the increase in sfGFP signal was TMP-dependent (
) and that TMP treatment affected neither mCherry expression (
). To probe translation rate at different cell cycle phases we used the CDK2 activity sensor (
) stably expressed in our U2OS cell line (U2OS
) and called this assay â€˜Cell cycle-dependent TRIPSâ€™ (C-TRIPS) (
Translation rate of AURKA APA isoforms follows different cell cycle periodicity
Design of the TRIPS reporters and assay (

Mean and s.e.m. of median sfGFP/mCherry MFI ratios from U2OS transfected with TRIPS-Î” and imaged at 0h and 2h of 50Î¼M TMP treatment, with or without 0.1mg/ml CHX, from three biological replicates. Baseline at 0h. n â‰¥ 55 cells per condition.
RT-qPCR of sfGFP mRNA from U2OS transfected with TRIPS-Î”, at 0h and 2h of 50Î¼M TMP treatment. mCherry mRNA used as reference target. RNA extracts at 0h of treatment used as reference sample.
. Mean and s.e.m. from three biological replicates.
. Median and 95% CI of pooled data from
. Kruskal-Wallis with Dunnettâ€™s multiple comparisons test.
RT-qPCR of endogenous AURKA mRNA in U2OS. 18S rRNA used as reference target. Baseline at G
Endogenous AURKA long isoform as in (E) plotted as percentage of total AURKA mRNA.
Ordinary one-way ANOVA with Tukeyâ€™s multiple comparisons test. ns, not significant; *, p<0.05; **, p<0.01; ***, p<0.0005; ****, p<0.0001.
To test the translation rate of the individual AURKA APA isoforms, we flanked DHFR-sfGFP CDS with AURKA PAS-mutated UTRs (TRIPS-L, TRIPS-S) (
). We found that our TRIPS assay could recapitulate the difference in translation efficiency of the isoforms previously observed (

). Importantly, expression of the CDK2 activity sensor did not affect cellular translation, as the different translation rate of AURKA 3â€™UTR isoforms could be reproduced in U2OS cells lacking the sensor (
). Following measurements of bulk translation rates (
), we then binned single-cell translation rate values into three intervals of CDK2 activity (

). Results of our C-TRIPS assay revealed that, while TRIPS-Î” is translated constantly during the cell cycle, translation rate of TRIPS-L is regulated in the cell cycle. This isoform showed lower translation rate in G
and S and an enhanced rate at G
, consistent with the increase in both AURKA mRNA and protein levels that occurs in preparation for mitosis (
). By contrast, TRIPS-S was translated constantly through the cell cycle and at a maximal rate already in G
), indicating that this isoform is insensitive to cell cycle regulation of AURKA translation rate.
Furthermore, we quantified abundance of endogenous AURKA APA isoforms at different stages of the cell cycle, by performing RT-qPCR following synchronization in G

). The expected changes in AURKA mRNA abundance following each treatment represent a positive control for the synchronization. However, abundance of the long isoform changed quite concomitantly with changes in total AURKA mRNA levels (

). This suggests that the same ratio of 3â€™UTR isoforms is rather maintained throughout the cell cycle and that AURKA APA is not cell cycle regulated. These results not only provide strong, independent validation of our finding that elements present in 5â€™ and 3â€™ UTR of AURKA enable translational activation but additionally indicate that elements present on the long 3â€™UTR might account for its different pattern of translation during interphase, as lack of these on the short 3â€™UTR allow escape from cell cycle phase-dependent translation.
Translational periodicity of long 3â€™UTR isoform is regulated by
Among known post-transcriptional regulators, miRNAs are widely recognized as molecular regulators of both mRNA stability and translation (
) to search for miRNAs that could be involved in the differential regulation of the two AURKA mRNA isoforms, and selected
miRNA given its widely established tumor-suppressor role of in TNBC. We assessed the
targeting of AURKA 3â€™UTR by co-transfecting our AURKA UTR-dependent protein expression reporters (

or a negative control miRNA that does not have any target in the human genome. As positive control of the assay, we cloned Myeloid Zinc Finger1 (MZF1) 3â€™UTR downstream Venus CDS in our Î” reporter and could reproduce the previously reported targeting of MZF1 3â€™UTR by
). Protein expression from the LONG reporter mRNA was reduced by
, whereas that from the SHORT mRNA and from a LONG mRNA that lacks the
targeting was sufficient to increase protein expression from the LONG reporter mRNA (compare LONG + NC vs Î”let7a + NC). To confirm that altered expression was due to the lack of
targeting and not an effect of the mutation itself, we also observed an increase in protein expression when we co-transfected our LONG reporter and an inhibitor of

or a negative control (NC) miRNA from three biological replicates. n â‰¥ 182 cells per condition. Unpaired t-test.
or NC. n â‰¥ 94 cells per condition. Unpaired t-test.

. Mean and s.e.m. from three biological replicates. Ordinary one-way ANOVA with Dunnettâ€™s multiple comparisons test vs NC.
. Median and 95% CI of pooled data from

In order to assess the role of
in controlling decay rate of the target mRNA, we next co-transfected our Venus reporters and either
or negative control miRNA and quantified reporter mRNA abundance after 8h of ActD treatment. We found that stability of the LONG reporter mRNA was significantly reduced by
, whereas that of the SHORT reporter mRNA was unaltered. Additionally, mutation of the
binding site slightly increased reporter mRNA stability (compare LONG + NC vs Î”let7a + NC) (
We then performed our C-TRIPS assay co-transfecting the TRIPS-L reporter and
or control miRNA and found that
) and translation rate at all interphase stages (
) of the long 3â€™UTR. Furthermore, we asked whether loss of
targeting is sufficient to cause loss of translational regulation of the long isoform during the cell cycle. For this, we performed the C-TRIPS assay using a TRIPS-L reporter with mutations in the
binding site (TRIPS-Î”let7a) or, alternatively, co-transfecting the TRIPS-L reporter and the
. Interestingly, in both cases, loss of
targeting only increased translation rate in G
), suggesting that the targeting in G
is not likely to occur unless in conditions of excess
In conclusion, our results show that
only silences AURKA long 3â€™UTR isoform by both promoting mRNA degradation and reducing translation rate, and that
targeting is responsible for the cell cycle-dependent translational regulation of AURKA long 3â€™UTR isoform.
Increased AURKA short/long ratio is sufficient to disrupt cell behavior

Having established that APA plays a role in regulating AURKA expression, we tested the idea that AURKA APA directly contributes to cancer cell behaviour, by performing genome editing to alter AURKA APA in wild-type U2OS cells. We used Cas9
-mediated double-nicking strategy and mutated the endogenous dPAS on
3â€™UTR with the aim of silencing expression of AURKA long 3â€™UTR isoform (
). Two mutant clones with disrupted dPAS site were obtained (Î”dPAS#1, Î”dPAS#2) (

) and were used for subsequent functional analyses. Qualitative assessment of AURKA 3â€™UTR isoforms ratio in these clones by 3â€™RACE found the long 3â€™UTR isoform to be undetectable in the mutated cell lines (
), indicating that the genetic editing successfully prevents usage of the dPAS site for cleavage and polyadenylation.
Increased AURKA short/long ratio is sufficient to disrupt cell behavior
Design of CRISPR editing. Nucleotide substitutions in red.
/S enrichment (C) and with or without 6h treatment with 0.1mg/ml CHX (D). Blots representative of three biological replicates.
CCK8 assay. A non-parental WT U2OS cell line used as negative control. Ordinary one-way ANOVA with Dunnettâ€™s multiple comparisons test vs WT; **, p<0.005; ***, p<0.001.
. Representative images of cells grown in soft agar.
. Mean number of clones and s.e.m. of three biological replicates.
Ordinary one-way ANOVA with Dunnettâ€™s multiple comparisons test vs WT; *, p<0.05; **, p<0.01.
We then examined expression of AURKA in the mutated cell lines by immunoblot of extracts from cell populations enriched for the G
/S phase of the cell cycle, where AURKA expression is the lowest in unmodified cells. We observed AURKA was expressed at higher levels in Î”dPAS#1 and Î”dPAS#2 cells compared to WT cells (
/S was reduced in the mutated cell lines when treated with CHX, indicating that translation of the short isoform is active in this phase (

). Because AURKA overexpression is a common feature of cancer, we interrogated the mutated cell lines for changes in cancer-relevant behaviour. Consistent with a role of AURKA overexpression in accelerating the cell cycle and favoring cell proliferation, we found a higher rate of proliferation of Î”dPAS#1 and Î”dPAS#2 cells compared to WT cells using the CCK8 assay to measure metabolic activity (

). Additionally, we assessed the ability of anchorage-independent growth, which closely correlates with tumorigenicity in animal models, by growing cells in soft agar. Î”dPAS#1 and Î”dPAS#2 cells resulted more capable to survive and grow in the absence of anchorage to their neighboring cells compared to WT cells (

). AURKA also regulates organization of microtubules required for cellular migration and it also enhances migration of tumor cells through several pathways. For example, AURKA activates the Cofilin-F-Actin pathway leading to breast cancer metastases (

). We were therefore prompted to assess the motility of Î”dPAS#1 and Î”dPAS#2 cells in a 2D cell migration assay. Our result shows a higher rate of migration of Î”dPAS#1 and Î”dPAS#2 cells compared to WT cells (
In summary, our results show that AURKA overexpression caused by a disruption in the SLR ratio of APA isoforms in favor of the short isoform contributes to cancer-like cell behavior.
In this study, we describe for the first time a molecular mechanism involving the dysregulation of APA and the differential targeting of AURKA APA isoforms by

, a tumor suppressor miRNA, that is sufficient for the oncogenic activation of AURKA at the post-transcriptional level. We also shed light on the cell cycle-dependent regulation of AURKA translation and introduce novel and improved methods for measurements of post-transcriptional gene expression of individual mRNAs of interest.

As a consequence of tandem 3â€™UTR APA, a short and a long 3â€™UTR isoform are generated for AURKA mRNA. The short/long ratio of these isoforms is cell-type defined and is not dependent on the cell cycle, indicating that cell-type specific/cell cycle-independent factors are involved in establishing the short/long ratio. This is unexpected given that periodic regulation of APA may be a characteristic of many cell cycle genes (

). Because protein expression differs from the two isoforms, AURKA short/long ratio is a crucial element defining AURKA expression levels. Ours and other studies detected increased short/long ratio of AURKA APA isoforms in TNBC and found this correlates with worse disease-free survival (

). Here we reveal insights into the molecular basis for the correlation, by showing that the increased and cell cycle-independent translation rate of the short isoform can lead to marked overexpression of AURKA in interphase. Our results support the hypothesis that deregulation of expression by disruption of APA is sufficient to drive AURKA oncogenic properties, such as promoting increased proliferation and migration rate. Whether this is also sufficient to drive cancer-cell transformation remains to be explored. It has been known for many years that overexpression of AURKA induces mitotic defects, aneuploidy, as well as acceleration of the cell cycle, epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and migration (
), whilst the cellular background for AURKAâ€™s transforming potential is also of importance (
). Nonetheless, the significance of AURKA overexpression specifically in G
for the exertion of potential oncogenic functions in this phase represents an emerging field of research (
). It is possible that normal AURKA functions are exerted at low levels of expression in G
become oncogenic at high levels of expression. This would not be surprising giving how the roles played by AURKA in G
revolve around regulation of transcription, mitochondria fitness and cellular metabolism.
Our work does not research the cause of the disrupted APA in TNBC. This could be concomitant to a global 3â€™UTR shortening, for example due to altered expression in cancer of C/P factors (
), or even altered RNA Pol II elongation dynamics (
). However, these phenomena have not been extensively explored in TNBC (

). Alternatively, disrupted APA could represent an AURKA gene-specific phenomenon due to presence of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) on the 3â€™UTR, either on the C/P site or in proximity, that could affect PAS choice by the C/P machinery. Finally, a mRNA-dependent mechanism whereby the short 3â€™UTR isoform itself regulates AURKA protein function or localization throughout or at specific phases of the cell cycle, licensing oncogenic advantage, should not be excluded (

The periodicity of AURKA expression is an important requirement for correct progression through the cell cycle. For example, ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis is a critical pathway for irreversible AURKA inactivation, which must occur for ordered transition to interphase following mitosis (

). One important but unanswered question is whether and to what extent translation regulation accounts for the increase and decrease of AURKA expression during the cell cycle. Implementation of our TRIPS assay, which measures protein synthesis rate independent of changes in mRNA abundance, allowed detection of active regulatory mechanisms of translation occurring at different cell cycle phases. This new evidence integrates well with the notion that transcriptional, post-transcriptional, and post-translational mechanisms all combine to provide
gene with a characteristic pattern of expression (
). Our work shows that translation of AURKA is regulated by
miRNA. Because we could still detect active protein synthesis from the long isoform under
overexpression using our TRIPS assay, and we could also immunoprecipitate tagged nascent chains from the long isoform in U2OS cells, where
is expressed, it is unlikely that
blocks translation at the level of initiation, but it rather slows down the rate of translation elongation. This is in accordance with a study showing that
), a generally proved mechanism of miRNA action (
). In addition, because we observed that
can also control the decay rate of the long isoform, it is possible that a reduction in translation elongation rate may be required to mediate degradation of the mRNA (
). We also show that the differential
targeting through the cell cycle is a mechanism responsible for AURKA periodic translational control. Based on evidence from our C-TRIPS assays to assess the temporal
targeting of the long isoform at different phases of the cell cycle, and on the published evidence that
levels are constant during the cell cycle of human cancer cells as well as untransformed fibroblasts (
and S, and is therefore responsible for the low AURKA translation rate in these phases; (ii) the targeting is not occurring in G
overexpression saturates sequestering factors that prevent its binding to the long isoform. Further investigations will be required to understand this mechanism in more detail.

The characterization of gene-specific post-transcriptional dynamics is desirable for a complete understanding of gene expression regulation. Here, we have developed transient single-cell and biochemical assays to rapidly study mRNA-specific gene expression in a way that measures post-transcriptional events exclusively. Importantly, the assays can be used to test the effect of regulators such as therapeutic miRNAs or drugs on protein expression, mRNA processing, and translation of selected genes.

In conclusion, our study reveals a strong cooperation between APA and miRNA targeting in controlling gene expression dynamics of AURKA and its oncogenic potential. It also provides a workflow to assess the role of mRNA-specific post-transcriptional processing and regulators. Our work additionally highlights a molecular mechanism that could represent an actionable target of RNA-based therapeutics.
Publicly available CEL files and associated metadata of microarray results were downloaded from NCBI Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository. APADetect tool (

) was used to detect and quantify APA events in TNBC patients and normal breast tissue. CEL files of Human Genome U133A (HGU133A, GPL96) and U133 Plus 2.0 Arrays (HGU133Plus2, GPL570) were analyzed to identify intensities of probes that were grouped based on poly(A) site locations extracted from PolyA_DB (

). Mean signal intensities of proximal and distal probe sets for AURKA were calculated and used as indicators of â€˜Shortâ€™ and â€˜Longâ€™ AURKA 3â€™-UTR isoformsâ€™ abundance. The ratio of proximal probe set mean (S) to the distal probe set (L) defined as short to long ratio (SLR). SLR values were subjected to significance analysis of microarrays (SAM), as implemented by the TM4 Multiple Array Viewer tool (
), for statistical significance after log normalization.

Live-cell microscopy was performed using Olympus IX81 motorized inverted microscope, Orca CCD camera (Hamamatsu Photonics, Japan), motorized stage (Prior Scientific, Cambridge, UK) and 37Â°C incubation chamber (Solent Scientific, Segensworth, UK) fitted with appropriate filter sets and a 40X NA 1.42 oil objective. Images were collected in the 490nm (Venus, sfGFP), 550nm (mCherry) and 435nm (CFP) channels using Micro-Manager software (
). Image analysis was performed using a customized plug-in tool (Andrew Ying, 2017) in Image J (

), which calculates mean fluorescence intensity (MFI) by measuring average, background-subtracted grey values over regions of interest (ROIs) of defined diameter around manually selected points in the cell.
Western blot was performed as previously described (

). PageRuler Prestained Protein Ladder (26616, ThermoFisher) was used. Primary antibodies used: mouse anti-AURKA mAb (1:1000; Clone 4/IAK1, BD Transduction Laboratories), rabbit anti-GFP (1:5000; Ab290, Abcam), rabbit anti-GAPDH (1:4000; 2118S, CST), mouse anti-mCherry (1:1000; ab167453, Abcam), mouse ANTI-FLAGÂ® M2 mAb (1:1000; F1804, Sigma). Secondary antibodies were rabbit (P044801-2) or mouse (P044701-2) HRP-conjugated (Dako, Agilent), used at 1:10000 dilution, and detection was performed via Immobilon Western Chemiluminescent HRP Substrate (WBKLS0100, Millipore) on an Odyssey Fc Dual-Mode Imaging System (LICOR Biosciences). RNA extracts were collected using Total RNA miniprep kit (T2010S, NEB). DNA was in-column digested with DNase I. Aliquots were stored with 5Î¼M EDTA at -20Â°C for a week or flash-frozen in dry ice and transferred at -80Â°C. A micro-volume spectrophotometer (NanoDropâ„¢ Lite, VWR) was used to assess A
ratios of 2.0-2.2. DNA contamination was also tested (

). RT-qPCR was performed using LunaÂ® Universal One-Step RT-qPCR Kit (E3005S, NEB). 20Î¼l reactions using 200nM primers and <100ng RNA were run on ABI StepOnePlus Real Time PCR system following manufacturerâ€™s instructions. Primers were designed at Eurofins Genomics. Î”C

method was used for relative quantifications accounting for the primer pairs amplification efficiency. Three technical replicates were performed in each biological replicate. Results shown as mean and s.e.m. of three biological replicates. Sequences of primers, validation of amplification efficiency of primer pairs, and checklist of MIQE guidelines (
. Microsoft Excel and GraphPad Prism were used for data analysis.

Cells were treated with 10Î¼g/ml Actinomycin D (ActD) (10043673, Fisher Scientific) and RNA was isolated from cells at the indicated time points after inhibition of transcription. Target mRNA was quantified by RT-qPCR using the Î”Î”C
method with indicated reference targets and corresponding RNA extracts at 0h of ActD treatment as reference sample. Mean and s.e.m. of three biological replicates are shown at each time point.

Transfected cells were treated with 0.1mg/ml CHX for 15 minutes, then washed, centrifuged, and resuspended in ice-cold lysis buffer [100mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 500mM LiCl, 10mM EDTA, 0.1mg/ml CHX, 0.1% Triton X-100, 100U/ml RNasin (3335399001, Merck) and cOmplete EDTA-free protease inhibitor cocktail (11836170001, Roche)] and incubated 15 minutes on ice. Lysates were cleared by centrifugation and supernatant was incubated with anti-Flag M2 magnetic beads (M8823, Sigma) overnight at 4 Â°C rotating. The bound fraction was washed twice (10mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 600mM LiCl, 1mM EDTA, 100U/ml RNasin, 0.1mg/ml CHX). Followed elution with 10mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 600mM LiCl, 1mM EDTA, 100U/ml RNAsin, 0.1mg/ml Puromycin (J67236.XF, Alfa Aesar), or with 3XFLAG peptide buffer (F4799, Sigma), for 30 minutes rotating at 4Â°C. RNA was purified (MonarchÂ® RNA Cleanup Kit, T2040L, NEB) from fractions and samples were stored as above. Aliquots of each fraction were mixed 1:1 with NuPAGEÂ® LDS Sample Buffer 4X (NP0007, Invitrogen), boiled 3 minutes at 95Â°C and stored at -20Â°C.

cDNA synthesis was performed using the Transcriptor Reverse Transcriptase (3531317001, Roche) with an oligo-dT anchor primer (5â€™-GACCACGCGTATCGATGTCGAC-TTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTV-3â€™). In the first round of PCR, an AURKA-specific forward primer (5â€™-TCCATCTTCCAGGAGGA-CCACTCTCTG-3â€™) was used with a reverse primer for the oligo-dT anchor sequence (Anchor_R: 5â€™-GACCACGCGTATCGATGTCGAC-3â€™). In the second round of PCR (nested), a new AURKA-specific forward primer (5â€™-CGGGATCCATATCACGGGTTGAATTCACATTC-3â€™) was used with Anchor_R. Nested PCR was performed using a 1:10 dilution of first PCR product as template. PCR product was visualized in agarose gels and imaged as above.
Two guide RNAs (gRNA1: 5â€²-GGCCAACAATGAACAGATGG-3â€² and gRNA2: 5â€²-GAGCAGGGGCTGAGAGGAGC-3â€²) were cloned into AIO-GFP (

), a gift from Steve Jackson (Addgene plasmid #74119). The donor DNA template for homology-directed repair (HDR) was cloned into a separate vector expressing mRuby (mRuby-HDR). AIO-GFP-gRNAs and mRuby-HDR were co-transfected into U2OS cells and 48h after transfection GFP

cells were sorted at single-cell density into multiple 96-well plates for clonal expansion. Cell populations were individually screened for dPAS mutation by touch-down PCR. Mutants were confirmed by Sanger sequencing of the genomic locus.

Cells were seeded into 96-well plates at a density of 4000 cells/well. CCK-8 (96992, Merck) was used according to the manufacturerâ€™s instructions and measurements were performed at the indicated time points. The OD
value was determined using a CLARIOstar Plus microplate reader (BMG LABTECH). Mean and s.e.m. of three biological replicates shown for each time point.
Colony formation assay in soft agar

A 0.6% base agarose was prepared in 6-well plates and cells were seeded at density of 15,000 cells per well prior mixing with agarose to a final agarose concentration of 0.3%. Fresh medium was added every 3 days. Colonies were imaged and counted after 10 days using phase contrast microscopy under 4X magnification.

A suspension of 50,000 cells was added to each well of a Culture-Insert 2 Well (IB-80209,Thistle Scientific Ltd) and grown into a monolayer. After insert removal, cells were washed and serum-free medium was added. At indicated time points, images of three different fields were acquired for every condition, using phase contrast microscopy under 10X magnification. The % of cell-free area was calculated using Wound_healing_size_tool plugin (
) in ImageJ and is shown as mean of three fields and s.e.m. for three biological replicates.

Graph Pad Prism 9 software (version 9.5.0) (Graph Pad Software Inc.) was used to generate graphs and perform statistical analyses. Statistical parameters including the sample size, the statistical test used, statistical significance (p value), and the number of biological replicates are reported in figure legends or methods.
